issues.text: whether in a writ in the nature of certiorari filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution the party or parties in whose favour a tribunal or authority had made an order, which is sought to be quashed, is or are necessary party or parties

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in a writ in the nature of certiorari filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution the party or parties in whose favour a tribunal or authority had made an order, which is sought to be quashed, is or are necessary party or parties. While learned Additional Solicitor General contends that in such a writ the said tribunal or authority is the only necessary party and the parties in whose favour the said tribunal or authority made an order or created rights are not necessary parties but may at best be only proper parties and that it is open to this Court, even at this very late stage to direct the impleading of the said parties for a final adjudication of the controversy,

issues.text: whether the Board of Revenue acted without jurisdiction in directing a fresh settlement, as neither r. 101 nor r. 145 of Excise Manual would apply to the facts of the case

anchor.surface_text: Learned Additional Solicitor General, appearing for the appellant, contended that the Board of Revenue acted without jurisdiction in directing a fresh settlement, as neither r. 101 nor r. 145 of Excise Manual would apply to the facts of the case r. 101 does not apply as in this case no licence was cancelled for malpractices, and r. 145 is not attracted as jadu Manjhi was not a licensee since no licence was issued in his favour. Learned counsel for the respondents raised, a preliminary objection that, as Phudan Manjhi and Bhagwan Rajak, who were necessary parties to the writ petition, were not made parties, the High Court was fully justified in dismissing the petition in limine.

issues.text: who are necessary or proper parties in a proceeding

anchor.surface_text: To answer the question raised it would be convenient at the outset to ascertain who are necessary or proper parties in a proceeding. The law on the subject is well settled it is enough if we state the principle. A necessary party is one without whom no order can be made effectively a proper party is one in whose absence an effective order can be made but whose presence is necessary for a complete and final decision on the question involved in the proceeding.

issues.text: what is the nature of a writ of certiorari ? What relief can a petitioner in such a writ obtain from the Court ?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is, what is the nature of a writ of certiorari ? What relief can a petitioner in such a writ obtain from the Court ? Certiorari lies to remove for the purpose of quashing the proceedings of inferior courts of record or other persons or bodies exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions. It is not necessary for the purpose of this appeal to notice the distinction between a writ of certiorari and a writ in the nature of certiorari in either case the High Court directs an inferior tribunal or authority to transmit to itself the record of proceedings pending therein for scrutiny and, if necessary, for quashing the same.

issues.text: whether the parties whose rights are directly affected are the necessary parties to a writ petition to quash the order of a tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the parties whose rights are directly affected are the necessary parties to a writ petition to quash the order of a tribunal. As we have seen, a tribunal or authority performs a judicial or quasi- judicial act after hearing parties. Its order affects the right or rights of one or the other of the parties before- it. In a writ of certiorari. the defeated party seeks for the quashing of the order issued by the tribunal in favour of the successful party.

arguments.claim: Tribunal exercising judicial/quasi-judicial function cannot decide against party without hearing; principles of natural justice require it if not in statute/rules

anchor.surface_text: A tribunal, therefore, exercising a judicial or quasi-judicial act cannot decide against the rights of 1 party without giving him a hearing or an opportunity to represent his case in the manner known to law. If the provisions of a particular statute or rules made thereunder do not provide for it, principles of natural justice demand it.

arguments.claim: High Court exercising certiorari jurisdiction must act judicially, make tribunal party; successful parties necessary as cannot quash their rights behind back

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the parties whose rights are directly affected are the necessary parties to a writ petition to quash the order of a tribunal. As we have seen, a tribunal or authority performs a judicial or quasi- judicial act after hearing parties. Its order affects the right or rights of one or the other of the parties before- it.

arguments.claim: English practice and Patna High Court rules require notice/service on persons directly affected/parties against whom relief sought

anchor.surface_text: The Rules made by the Patna High Court require that a party against whom relief is sought should be named in the petition. The relevant Rules read thus Rule 3. ... Rule 5. The notice of the application shall be served on all persons directly affected and on such other persons as the Court may direct.

arguments.claim: Precedents from Bombay HC and Nagpur HC hold tribunal and affected parties necessary in writ to quash order

anchor.surface_text: A division Bench of the Bombay High Court in Ahmedalli v. M. D. Lalkaka 1 laid down the procedure thus ... A Full Bench of the Nagpur High Court in Kanglu Baula v. Chief Executive Officer 2 held that ... persons who were declared elected ... were not joined as parties ...

holdings.text: In a writ of certiorari not only the tribunal or authority whose order is sought to be quashed but also parties in whose favour the said order is issued are necessary parties.

anchor.surface_text: To summarize in a writ of certiorari not only the tribunal or authority whose order is sought to be quashed but also parties in whose favour the said order is issued are necessary parties. But it is in the discretion of the court to add or implead proper parties for completely settling all the questions that may be involved in the controversy either suo motu or on the application of a party to the writ or an application filed at the instance of such proper party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from definition of necessary parties, requirement of effective orders, natural justice principles prohibiting adverse orders without hearing, English practice, Patna HC rules, and precedents from Bombay and Nagpur HCs.

holdings.text: A necessary party is one without whom no order can be made effectively; a proper party is one in whose absence an effective order can be made but whose presence is necessary for a complete and final decision on the question involved in the proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: To answer the question raised it would be convenient at the outset to ascertain who are necessary or proper parties in a proceeding. The law on the subject is well settled it is enough if we state the principle. A necessary party is one without whom no order can be made effectively a proper party is one in whose absence an effective order can be made but whose presence is necessary for a complete and final decision on the question involved in the proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stated as well-settled principle of law on parties in proceedings.

holdings.text: The authority or tribunal whose order is sought to be quashed is certainly a necessary party to a writ of certiorari proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances whoever else is a necessary party or not the authority or tribunal is certainly a necessary party to such a proceeding. In this case, the Board of Revenue and the Commissioner of Excise were rightly, made parties in the writ petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary to transmit records and bound by quashing order; otherwise can ignore High Court order.

holdings.text: A petition for writ of certiorari without impleading necessary parties like successful parties is incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Such a party, therefore, is a necessary party and a petition filed for the issue of a writ of certiorari without making him a party or without impleading him subsequently, if allowed by the court, would certainly be incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quashing order ineffective without them; rights continue despite quashing; violates natural justice.

holdings.text: Certiorari lies to quash proceedings of inferior courts or bodies exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions.

anchor.surface_text: Certiorari lies to remove for the purpose of quashing the proceedings of inferior courts of record or other persons or bodies exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions. It is not necessary for the purpose of this appeal to notice the distinction between a writ of certiorari and a writ in the nature of certiorari in either case the High Court directs an inferior tribunal or authority to transmit to itself the record of proceedings pending therein for scrutiny and, if necessary, for quashing the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled law; applies Atkin test for judicial/quasi-judicial acts.

holdings.text: A tribunal exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions cannot decide against a party without giving hearing; principles of natural justice demand it if not provided in statute/rules.

anchor.surface_text: A tribunal, therefore, exercising a judicial or quasi-judicial act cannot decide against the rights of 1 party without giving him a hearing or an opportunity to represent his case in the manner known to law. If the provisions of a particular statute or rules made thereunder do not provide for it, principles of natural justice demand it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent in judicial duty; extends to High Court in certiorari jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The request to implead necessary parties at late stage and remand to High Court is belated and cannot be granted.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant suggests that this Court may at this very late stage direct them to be made parties and remand the matter to the High Court for disposal. This request is belated and cannot, therefore, be granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural discretion; too late after High Court dismissal and special leave.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly rejected the writ petition as incompetent due to non-impleadment of necessary parties.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the petition filed by him was incompetent and was rightly rejected. That order was made on July 3, 1962 and the special leave petition was- filed on July 18, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of necessary parties rule to facts; accepts respondent's preliminary objection.

precedents.cited_proposition: classic test for judicial act: Wherever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench Division exercised in these writs

anchor.surface_text: Lord justice Slesser in The King v. London County Council 2 dissected the concept of judicial act laid down by Atkin, L. J., into the following heads in his judgment wherever any body

precedents.case_name: The King v. London County Council
precedents.cited_proposition: dissected the concept of judicial act into: 1 having legal authority 2 to determine questions affecting rights of subjects and 3 having the duty to act judicially 4 act in excess of their legal authority
precedents.cited_holding: dissected the concept of judicial act laid down by Atkin, L. J., into the following heads: wherever any body of persons 1 having legal authority 2 to determine questions affecting rights of subjects and 3 having the duty to act judicially 4 act in excess of their legal authority a writ of certiorari may issue

anchor.surface_text: A division Bench of the Bombay High Court in Ahmedalli v. M. D. Lalkaka 1 laid down the procedure thus I think we should lay down the rule of prac- tice that whenever a writ is sought challenging the order of a Tribunal, the Tribunal must always be a necessary party to the petition.

precedents.cited_proposition: whenever a writ is sought challenging the order of a Tribunal, the Tribunal must always be a necessary party to the petition. It is equally clear that all parties affected by that order should also be necessary parties to the petition
precedents.cited_holding: I think we should lay down the rule of practice that whenever a writ is sought challenging the order of a Tribunal, the Tribunal must always be a necessary party to the petition. It is difficult to understand how under any circumstances the Tribunal would not be a necessary party when the petitioner wants the order of the Tribunal to be quashed or to be called in question. It is equally clear that all parties affected by that order should also be necessary parties to the petition.

precedents.citation: Kanglu Baula v. Chief Executive Officer 2

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Nagpur High Court in Kanglu Baula v. Chief Executive Officer 2 held that though the elections to various electoral divisions were void the petition would have to be dismissed on the short ground that persons who were declared elected from the various constituencies were not joined as parties to the petition

precedents.case_name: Kanglu Baula v. Chief Executive Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: though the elections to various electoral divisions were void the petition would have to be dismissed on the short ground that persons who were declared elected from the various constituencies were not joined as parties to the petition and had not been given an opportunity to be heard before the order adverse to them was passed
precedents.cited_holding: though the elections to various electoral divisions were void the petition would have to be dismissed on the short ground that persons who were declared elected from the various constituencies were not joined as parties to the petition and had not been given an opportunity to be heard before the order adverse to them was passed

anchor.surface_text: To summarize in a writ of certiorari not only the tribunal or authority whose order is sought to be quashed but also parties in whose favour the said order is issued are necessary parties. But it is in the discretion of the court to add or implead proper parties for completely settling all the questions that may be involved in the controversy either suo motu or on the application of a party to the writ or an application filed at the instance of such proper party.

Learned counsel for the respondents raised, a preliminary objection that, as Phudan Manjhi and Bhagwan Rajak, who were necessary parties to the writ petition, were number made parties, the High Court was fully justified in dismissing the petition in limine.

To answer the question raised it would be convenient at the outset to ascertain who are necessary or proper parties in a proceeding. The law on the subject is well settled it is enough if we state the principle. A necessary party is one without whom no order can be made effectively a proper party is one in whose absence an effective order can be made but whose presence is necessary for a complete and final decision on the question involved in the proceeding.

Learned counsel for the respondents raised, a preliminary objection that, as Phudan Manjhi and Bhagwan Rajak, who were necessary parties to the writ petition, were number made parties, the High Court was fully justified in dismissing the petition in limine.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances whoever else is a necessary party or not the authority or tribunal is certainly a necessary party to such a proceeding. In this case, the Board of Revenue and the Commissioner of Excise were rightly, made parties in the writ petition.

Learned counsel for the respondents raised, a preliminary objection that, as Phudan Manjhi and Bhagwan Rajak, who were necessary parties to the writ petition, were number made parties, the High Court was fully justified in dismissing the petition in limine.

anchor.surface_text: Such a party, therefore, is a necessary party and a petition filed for the issue of a writ of certiorari without making him a party or without impleading him subsequently, if allowed by the court, would certainly be incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Certiorari lies to remove for the purpose of quashing the proceedings of inferior courts of record or other persons or bodies exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions. It is not necessary for the purpose of this appeal to notice the distinction between a writ of certiorari and a writ in the nature of certiorari in either case the High Court directs an inferior tribunal or authority to transmit to itself the record of proceedings pending therein for scrutiny and, if necessary, for quashing the same.
